headline: Straight downhill in the past 18 months
pros: The money the past 2 years or so has been great, but it doesn't make up for the way we are being treated.
cons:
I came from BB&T before the merger with SunTrust to form Truist. We had a fantastic team. We had a rhythm, got our work done, were trusted by our management and had some fun along the way.

The "new" mentality is teammate (employee) = stupid, lazy, inept. High priced consultant= smart.

I have seen outstanding employees with decades of experience who are leaders in their fields completely marginalized in favor of bringing in high paid consultants. The consultants don't know our systems, history, business, and in many cases don't even know the basics of the tools they were hired to implement. They deliver sub-par work then they move on to the next 6 or 7 figure project that we hire them for and the teammates are left to sweep up the poop off the floor.

During a recent go-live our contractors did the bare minimum then dropped broken incomplete work on the employees as they moved on. We put in 80+ hour weeks including some 20 hour days. We missed weekends, holidays, evenings, medical appointments. Just keep working. Unacceptable.

The culture of BB&T is gone and the new culture is one that I am not interested in working in.

headline: Edge $ell
pros: Working here you will get to meet a lot of people. It will give you the opportunity to keep an eye out for recruiters in your area at other companies, local businesses with open opportunities, maybe a bank area leader from a smaller bank that cares is a client ect.
cons: Working while short staffed year after year can be frustrating, especially when there's been requests for more help and they are denied. Additionally, there is a lot of confusion because the bank does not offer training or up to date resources. If you receive training, they will expect you to force yourself through it and guess while taking clients. You won't remember a thing you trained on. Training time would take you away from your ability to sell and the bank is short to begin with. No one knows what they are doing because we are all abandoned with no clear direction. The wait times are so outlandish that all you have to do is make 2-3 calls with a client and your day is over. During the wait times, you can update your resume in the background. The only direction made clear by higher ups is to sell and sell more. Most of the time you just want break maybe one meal/facility break during the week, or maybe you want that pto day approved that your boss tells you not to key in the request, because it is too short to let you use your pto. The bank will say that they are about work life balance but they never tell you the ratio of that balance, you'll find that out yourself. The bank will go over metrics, spreadsheets all week for sales, but as soon as you provide them with metrics like how their pay isn't competitive enough to the market or how other branches might be staffed more who happen to be chummy with their leadership, they clam up and no longer want to use metrics. I would say overall morale is going to be one of the biggest cons, if you have worked here for a while and people trust you, they will openly tell you that they are considering or planning an exit regardless of their tenure. No one feels appreciated no matter how many generic e-mails come out saying that they appreciate the thousand recipients in the e-mail.

headline: Hard
pros: The pro's are that you have a job.
cons: It is very frustrating when you come into work and the same problems persist every single day for months and years. It is hard to have your voice heard although you receive generic emails to thousands saying that "Truist Cares" although you never feel or see the caring. Your clients have normal expectations although the company does not give you the resources, support or motivation to meet the needs of customers. The processes are so unclear and procedures changing daily, you'll never know what is right vs wrong, nor where to check, who to call ect. The systems are constantly broken and things getting moved around. You are left abandoned with very high and unrealistic goals. There is no incentive to reach these goals because if you do, they will get higher and you won't get paid for doing so. The incentives are so low compared to other banks, I am surprised they call them incentives here. If you perform better than everyone then you will be rewarded with the same reward as everyone else. The low performers may even be paid higher than you in most cases. The pay is not worth the amount of work and torture you will succumb to. There is always turnover and the new people have less training than most banks, they are set up for instant failure. The existing people have no voice and are unappreciated to say the least, so morale is very low no matter what you are trying to get done. The bank is extremely high paced with upset clients due to the issues and you will have to be that person to fix something that maybe someone else messed up because they just don't care anymore. It becomes very frustrating when this goes on for so long. The new Truist company does not send anyone around like the previous heritage organization did, so you can never share your sentiments and frustrations. They are afraid to see or hear the truth and would rather hide. The teammate surveys don't even come out anymore after they got so low consistently, they just don't want feedback. It is very difficult to obtain a break or use facilities because every location is extremely short, I don't even bring water in to drink or food anymore because of this and this is years on in. Nothing looks like it will ever get fixed. Sales goals continue to go up as customer service score goals continue to decrease. The expectation is that you sell and when you do, the person you refer to may be on their way out or just bogged down and not motivated themselves because the lack of appreciation is not limited to one department. If your sale goes a few weeks before your person works it, you are lucky and by then the client is not interested anymore and found another bank. If for some reason they happen to be interested, then the sale might not book properly because the bank has issues with sales reporting properly and you will be asked to fill out an excel sheet remembering any sales in the last 3 months that have not posted which is an impossible task being that you can't even take a break due to the staffing shortages. In short, you basically will not get the sale anyways and it will reflect your performance and pay and advancement ect because the bank does not know how to run their company properly and keep everyone happy. You will also be lacking significant training and continue to receive more and more tasks and responsibilities with no pay. When ever changes come, you will never be made aware until you have a live client in front of you which makes bad client experiences. Someone will say oh that was in an email like few months ago, meanwhile you have no time to read emails because you are so short staffed and the bank can't afford to allow you to be away and take training. The low pay for the work is going to have every recruiter in the area reaching out to you if you make a linkedin and say that you work here. Every place knows that Truist is not doing well and pays very low so you will receive constant offers to interview elsewhere. The call times at Truist will drive you insane because you may not even be calling the correct department and the clients are upset about them so they come inside and you literally have to tell them that you call the same number and they want to flip over your desk. It is a very tough job for the pay, if the pay was a fair wage I would say come to the bank but it has all of the headaches of a big bank but lacks the pay to a significant level that you would rather panhandle on the streets than work here. The short staffing is unbelievable and it makes your team cry. I try daily to make sure my team doesn't cry. I would say look elsewhere if you are considering working here

BBT was the best company I had ever worked for and I felt like there were unlimited career opportunities as well as outstanding support for employees across the entire organization. Unfortunately, the company was taken over by Sun Trust. Two years into this merger (takeover) and Truist is now the worst company I've ever worked for and there are ZERO career opportunities. Truist does not promote, there have been none for two years, and the company does not give raises to managers. Hundreds of employees have jumped ship, most of them excellent BBT managers who have been forced out via early retirement. Suntrust (Truist) is a company run by contractors at many levels. They do not understand nor do they care about process, best practice, or standards. The former CEO of BBT, once beloved by his people, is now looked upon by his ex-employees as someone who just destroyed not only the company but his legacy and left us all holding a big steaming bag. Kelly King got his golden parachute and in the process BBT  is history. His legacy is that he betrayed all of his employees and he is no longer much liked or seen as anyone who accomplished anything. If you're looking for a career or an organization where you'll feel supported keep looking. This place is a disaster. Many managers have between 20 and 200 direct employees because they've eliminated so many management layers to save money. So many careers have been destroyed by the takeover and I don't know of anyone who is happy here.

headline: Decent Stability

cons: Where to begin......for what it’s worth, this bank did not seem 100% ready to merge. It has not been a smooth process for the clients, ESPECIALLY the employees in the South Florida market. A lot of BB&T employees have a really bad culture, bad attitude and bad habits. Most of the employees both at Suntrust and BB&T have had the same job titles for years. You’ll find people that have been relationship bankers for 10+ years and are fine with that. That could be because they are lazy or it is unlikely they will receive a promotion. Also, C Level management went around asking employees for their opinion as far as “What should our new name and slogan be?” “What color scheme should we roll out?” All these minuscule questions that shows us as employees that they probably weren’t very ready to merge. Honestly, the only good thing about BB&T is they have an outstanding commercial RE lending product and Suntrust has a decent home equity line product. If you are looking for an institution to to spend 10-20 years at, if you’re 10 years away from retirement and wants pension, or if you’re young and just need the banking experience, then this is the place for you. But if you’re considering switching employers in South Florida, stay far away. Also, the quarterly bonuses are a joke!

Technology lags behind industry trends but the company is making strides to improve. In recent years there have been significant changes to modernize systems including CI, Cloud, and Data. This also presents unique opportunities for those with modern skills. Their website and app are among the cleanest of the big banks too.

The retirement package is impressive with a 6% 401k match after a year of service and a small pension plan starting after five years of service. The pension works out to a yearly payout in retirement of 1% of your salary multiplied by the number of years you worked at Truist so it isn't enough to retire on but should provide some extra spending money in the twilight years. Health insurance has several options and can be reasonably affordable though this comes with a catch. Benefits information can be easily found through a public website so you know what to expect when going through interviews.

As a whole the company is in a strong position to be a major player in the banking space. The brand is respected as is the CEO and they have offices in hot areas like Charlotte, Raleigh, and Atlanta. If the company can make some key pivots in their approach to technology and their treatment of technology employees then there is a lot of potential for success and growth.
cons:
Overall compensation for technology jobs needs a major overhaul. Paid time off is an embarrassing 10 days and doesn't increase to 15 until five years of service. Some recent hires have negotiated for 15 to start but the idea of people having to negotiate to get the industry minimum standard is sad. Employees do get 10 sick days a year but good luck using more than half without getting an earful. Health insurance is only affordable if you participate in an intrusive health monitoring program that regularly checks everything from your bloodwork to your body fat percentage to your eating habits and even your oxygen levels. Vision and dental plans are middle of the road.

Salaries are 10-20% below the industry average. In early 2020 senior leadership hired a firm to evaluate the company salary bands and promised that changes would be made based on the findings. Though the study was completed in late 2020 the data has still not been released to employees in spite of leadership saying that it would be transparent. The only changes made were updates to broaden job bands which led to less descriptive job titles and wider salary spreads with even low level engineering roles in the same area now having a spread of over 30k. Meanwhile leadership claims that the study found the company salaries to be fair without providing proof. Leadership has also ignored any questions in town halls about the study or low salaries and even angrily announced at a call in the spring that they were tired of being asked about low pay and wouldn't answer those questions again. In this same frustrated exchange the leadership person talking accidentally let it slip that the study had found most employees were within 20% of the industry midpoints. Realizing their mistake they quickly tried to put a positive spin by pivoting to the benefits and claiming that the 20% figure was really good compared to some places. Bonuses are also misleading. If you qualified for say a 15% bonus then really you'd get 10% as a good performer. Along with the salary study leadership had also announced that bonuses would be revamped to be more competitive but all they really did was make it look nicer without being any better. Instead of the old 15% bonus you now qualify for a range of 0-30% so recruiters can tell prospective hires they can get up to a 30% bonus but really it's still a 10% payout. Don't expect to catch up with raises either. Recruitment and senior leadership constantly talk about pay for performance but raises barely keep up with inflation and the difference between a high and low performer will be a fraction of a percent. Pay for performance here really means that you'll pay for good performance by being asked to take on more work.

Nearly every technology group is being stretched to their limit and then a bit further still. Expect to work at least 50 hours a week in a more reasonable group or 60+ in more critical teams. Certain key contributors and backend support teams are regularly putting in over 80 hours. This can include nights, weekends, holidays, and vacation days. What's most frustrating about the overwork is that there isn't any clear reason for it. Senior leadership keeps using the merger as an excuse to come up with crazy deadlines but they aren't consulting with the business side or with the employees that know the products to determine if a date makes sense or if mandated work is necessary at all. When people question a deadline senior leadership says it has to be met because we committed to the date but they gloss over the part where they created the date and the project in the first place and committed the team without asking. Of course when teams miss a deadline they get chewed out by their boss's boss and in the event a team succeeds then their boss's boss takes most of the credit. Coupled with the low pay and lack of vacation time many groups are facing a high degree of turnover that leadership refuses to openly acknowledge. In one town hall when someone asked how leadership was addressing the burnout and churn leadership responded by saying that they work hard too and we should think about the impact our work will have for the customers.

The handling of the merger and Covid have been messy. There were cases where teams were told that they'd have to relocate then after half the team had moved or quit the teams were told they could stay put for the moment and even then leadership refuses to take a firm position on whether future relocations will or won't be needed. Some teams have had several managers within the course of a year along with changing priorities each time. Suntrust and BBT were two very different companies and leaders from both keep trying to make power moves leading to a lot of confusion and backpedaling on projects. Prior to Covid the company was expressly against any remote work and while the stance has shifted somewhat to a hybrid model leadership has yet to define how this hybrid will work and is still against any permanent remote possibilities. Senior leadership keeps claiming that they're hearing from everyone about a desire to go back to the office but I've yet to meet anyone outside senior leadership that is eager to go back. While other companies have gone the extra mile to make sure that employees feel appreciated in these trying times Truist has taken a decidedly different approach. Instead of extra days off, impromptu raises, or meaningful gifts employees here instead have gotten items like a book about the history and importance of Truist or a little Truist pin that we're encouraged to wear on our clothes to show our Truist pride. The most embarrassing was perhaps the pamphlet every employee received touting the culture of diversity at Truist yet on page two there was a picture of the executive team which is almost exclusively a bunch of old white guys in suits.

Adoption of agile is the typical scaled waterfall approach. If you've had even a cursory training on agile principles then you'll recognize that much of what teams are told to do doesn't make sense. Need to size a story? The agile leadership group tells teams to use a chart that directly equates points to a set number of days. Team struggling to get work done in a sprint? Let's close the old stories and open new ones for remaining tasks. Want to increase velocity? Double the team size then wonder why so many meetings run over. Finishing a Big Room planning? Instead of putting dependent stories on the boards for other teams it's better to use a series of confusing excel documents in Sharepoint. Looking for agile training? Agile leadership are too busy trying to look good to senior leadership to do any real coaching so here's a brief Powerpoint to review instead.

While the company is slowly improving it's technologies it can't seem to let go of old practices that slow everyone down. Each month there are several hours of mandatory eLearnings that have nothing to do with your job role. Assigned laptops are mid spec and only get replaced after five years of use. Developers can only have standard access to their own machines, no Admin or Elevated rights, and can only have software installed through a dated ticketing system. Getting new software added to the list takes months if the request gets accepted at all. Little to no money is approved for personal development like certification courses or local conferences. A mandatory Outlook plugin forces you to select a risk classification every single time you send an email. Perhaps the biggest issue with process is the compartmentalization of product components. Within the same product there can be separate teams for web, web services, backend, and database and while most people get along every team has it's own separate and often contradictory processes.

The senior leadership at Truist is out of touch. They think that building a positive culture means coming up with fancy statements without having to change how the business operates. They claim transparency but prescreen town hall questions, have a system in place to track who asked a particular question, and avoid any touchy topics. They say we're all in this together yet can't be bothered to set up a skip level or send a legitimate gift to express gratitude as we're expected to work late nights, weekends, and holidays to meet the awful deadlines that they imposed. While the company pulls in record numbers and leadership gives themselves big bonuses or promotions for successes achieved by our hard work our already low salaries stagnant under disappointing raises. The same leadership team that insists a software developer who never interacts with clients has to come into the office several times a week and is unprofessional wearing anything less than khakis and a tucked in dress shirt also wonders why the company has issues recruiting developers in some of the hottest locations in the country or why anyone would leave.

Mergers in general are chaotic, but this is a whole new level.

The diversity within SunTrust was amazing. The culture was amazing, and sr. Leadership was amazing. Since the merger, it seems you can only thrive if you’re a straight white man. headline: This Bank Does Not Give Equal Consideration to Women's Well-Being & Misrepresents Their Benefits
pros: Overall working at Truist is fine but I was very disappointed to see how they misrepresent their maternity leave.
cons:
The company claims to give birthing mothers 16 weeks maternity leave. What they mean by that is that you can take UP TO 16 weeks, if you wish to take longer with your PTO, you need to get special permission. Also, no matter how long you take (16 weeks or less), you are forced to use ALL of your sick time (which is impossible following corporate policy since you will have doctors appointments and need to log that time away as sick time). Since you will not have enough remaining sick time to cover this 2 week period, you then have the choice of using your PTO or going unpaid. When you return from having a baby, if you do not have PTO or sick time left, and if you get sick, you go unpaid. The bank does not quietly misrepresent their maternity benefit for birthing mothers; they proudly socialize it as 16 weeks. 14 weeks is still a good benefit time for the US but the fact that Truist forces one to use their sick time, PTO or going unpaid for 2 weeks, is the problem. 

Truist is fostering an environment where expecting birthing mothers will most likely avoid taking their allotted PTO before giving birth or use their sick time when sick. Since you do not know how much sick time you will have by the time you give birth, due to the numerous doctors appointments one needs to attend, and the fact that you may get sick, you need to reserve your PTO. And since whatever remaining sick time one has left when they give birth HAS to FULLY go towards your maternity leave (as if giving birth is an illness/sickness or a disability), one needs to save their PTO in case they do get sick or their child gets sick- otherwise you go unpaid. The company preaches financial well being and setting people up for success but are more than comfortable putting new parents in a situation where they can go unpaid when they potentially need their paycheck the most. They are also giving no thoughtfulness towards the mental well being of their birthing teammates, one should have the option to take time off and get a break and not have their entire year dedicated to giving birth. 
Another interesting factor of using your sick time towards maternity leave, is if it occurs on a public holiday, you still need to use the sick day, even though the bank is closed. It is standard to not get holidays during your leave but when you are requiring personal sick days to be used (which is only required for birthing mothers- not any other parental leave) and the bank isn't even open, it is absolutely ridiculous. 
Also, Truist isn't creating opportunities to help their parenting teammates or help retain their talent. If you would like or need to take additional unpaid time off, you will lose your job. I understand the company has absolutely no legal obligation to hold your position but a manager should have discretion that if one wants to potentially extend their parental leave, that the company does not have to lose you. Potentially the amount of extra time you wish/need to take, might take the company just as long to replace you and lose even more months of productivity getting a new person up to speed.  
The company prides itself as being an innovative, new age bank and is (understandably) proud to be one of the top 6 banks in the US but they are not reaching their competitor's standards on benefits. Case in point the complaint above, nor do they offer adequate family planning, such as IVF, which has become a standard in the banking community. It clearly still has the mindset of a regional conversative bank.

headline: Rapidly becoming Wells Fargo
pros: You will appreciate your time away from work more. You will have more patience with your children. You will not be upset when stuck in traffic.
cons:
The conglomeration of two giant entities has created so much bureaucracy that it's difficult discerning between Truist and working for an actual government body.

The retail community bank is so desperately short-staffed across the board that teams at some branches consist of 2 people for weeks at a time--meaning no lunch breaks, no break of any kind, furious customers, and exhausted staff. Truist is obviously consolidating at a rapid pace and the effort appears to be intended to have people quit in order to prevent Truist from performing additional or at the very least as many layoffs next year. 

If you are used to old school banking or even a former BB&T employee, you will not recognize this bank. Suntrust leadership has and continues to fill leadership roles on the community bank side. Their branch leaders haven't keyed loans in a decade. They let an actual small business specialist talk to clients over the phone. They are the epitome of tick mark chasers, are so out of touch with how banking and finance work they it is scary, and they, because they are unable to do anything themselves, have really increased their corporate koolaid rhetoric and displaying fluff when the BB&T counterparts have actual production goals. The staff at Suntrust branches are lazy, rude to clients, refuse to help clients without an appointment, routinely don't answer the phone, and are the robots Suntrust turned them into. If you like chasing tick marks, having no understanding of how loans or really anything having to do with banking, then a heritage Suntrust opening might be for you.

The effect of Covid has pushed retail CB leadership to the brink of becoming 100% lemmings from an expense perspective. Here's a great example: an RBM decided his region shouldn't buy dog treats for pass back in the drive thru. Now, no one can order them through our requisition system. Tellers are going out and buying them. Tellers, making $15/hr, have to buy their own dog treats to hand back. If you hate animals or like making people who work hard for the little they have use it to promote the best interest of Truist, then this bank is for you.

Truist took the income made of the PPP loan program at the corporate level instead of at the region or branch level, in spite of the community bank (branch leaders) processing them. Over 100,000. Great news though: they did give out a gift card to BLs who worked for months, often through the night and on weekends: $500. The bank collected almost $600 Million in fees for the loans, so that seems pretty fair. The issue is that months of focus on PPP loans takes away focus from the branch, and while they did reduce goals slightly, the PPP Loans definitely impacted overall production and consequently payouts.

Pressure is already huge this year. BLs need to call 50 small business clients a week, with branch staff making 20 dials each a day. Even with branches with 2 people. If you don't have an equity line keyed by Wednesday, you have to Stay for a call Thursday in which an execution leader, who has nothing better to do than send 50 emails a day on how you're bad at your job, and your RBM have you call 10 clients to pitch HELOCs. You can have 10 last week... But 0 through Wednesday and you have to join. Certainly more examples but this seems sufficient a description.

Lastly, human resources, branch information, and certain other back office groups are so short-staffed that it quite literally takes hours on hold to accomplish anything. This isn't being dramatic: it truly takes hours.
